title: A First Class Solution
categories: Supportive Housing Interventions for Formerly Homeless Persons; Homelessness Policy Analysis and Commentary
abstract: The success of the Housing First movement shows why social service providers must listen to the people they serve. - See more at: http://ssir.org/book_reviews/entry/a_first_class_solution#sthash.EeWn9Odo.dpuf

title: Child Welfare Involvement Among Children in Homeless Families
authors: Jung Min Park, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
categories: Child Welfare and Out-of-home Placement; Homelessness among Families with Children; Homelessness
abstract: An analysis of 8,251 homeless children in New York City found that 18% of them received child welfare services over the five-year period following their first shelter admission, and an additional 6% had a history of having received such services before their first shelter admission. Recurrent use of public shelters, exposure to domestic violence, older age at first episode of homelessness, and larger number of children in a household were associated with an increased risk of child welfare involvement. The high rate of crossover between homelessness and the child welfare system suggests the need for service coordination for children in homeless families.
